title: Bug

verbs: To creep; to move slowly on hands and knees, or by dragging the body along the ground.
Move slowly; in the case of people or animals with the body near the ground
To move slowly with the body in a prone position resting on or close to the ground.
To move slowly with the abdomen close to the ground.
nouns: Insects are a class of invertebrates within the arthropod phylum that have a chitinous exoskeleton, a three-part body, three pairs of jointed legs, compound eyes and one pair of antennae.
A class of the Arthropoda typically having a segmented body with an external chitinous covering, a pair of compound eyes, a pair of antennae, three pairs of mouthparts, and two pairs of wings.
An arthropod in the class Insecta, characterized by six legs, up to four wings, and a chitinous exoskeleton.
Class of invertebrates within the arthropod phylum
The wormlike larva of a butterfly or moth.
The larva of a butterfly or moth; leafworm.
Caterpillar is the common name for the larvae of members of the order Lepidoptera.
A wormlike and often brightly colored and hairy or spiny larva of a butterfly or moth
General term for any insect or similar creeping or crawling invertebrate
A generally tubular invertebrate of the annelid phylum.
Animal that typically have a long tube-like body and no legs
Any of numerous relatively small elongated soft-bodied animals especially of the phyla Annelida and Chaetognatha and Nematoda and Nemertea and Platyhelminthes; also many insect larvae
The term worm is used in everyday language to describe many different distantly related animals that typically have a long cylindrical tube-like body and no legs.

description:
A bug, or insect, generally depicted as a caterpillar, which becomes a ü¶ã Butterfly. Shown in full profile facing left, inching up on the back of its green, segmented, and textured body. Often featuring black stripes or yellow dots and tentacles on its head.

May be used to represent various insects, worms, and related animals. May also be used for metaphorical senses of bug.

Twitter’s bug is purple. Apple’s bug is hairy with a red head and legs and black stripes on its body. Facebook’s bug also has a yellowish-orange head. Google and Microsoft’s bugs previously resembled an orange centipede or millipede, and Samsung’s had a cartoon-styled face with a purple nose.
apple_vendor_description: Apple‚Äôs bug emoji presents a small, vibrant creature with an endearing, rounded form and a glossy finish, rendered with Apple's signature 3D shading. Its tiny antennae and segmented body are depicted with playful detail, often in a bright green or brown hue that feels both natural and charming on Apple devices. While sometimes used to represent insects, it's also playfully employed to signify a glitch, a problem, or something that needs fixing.
